english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Amr ibn al-Zubair: When this verse was revealed: 'Guard yourselves against a trial which, if it befalls, will not smite exclusively those among you who are unjust in their dealings' (Surah Al-Anfal 25), Abu Bakr, Umar, Ali, and Uthman were present with the Prophet ﷺ. Abu Bakr asked: 'O Messenger of Allah ﷺ, where shall I be at that time?' He replied: 'Under the earth.' Then Umar stood and asked: 'O Messenger of Allah ﷺ, where shall I be at that time?' He said: 'Under the earth.' Then Uthman stood and asked: 'O Messenger of Allah ﷺ, where shall I be at that time?' He replied: 'You will open through it and conflict will arise through it.' Then Ali stood and asked: 'O Messenger of Allah ﷺ, where shall I be at that time?' He said: 'You are their Imam and their guide, walking through it like a camel in its tether.'

The other man said he obtained it from a share of war booty. The Ansari brought him to the Prophet ﷺ. The Prophet ﷺ said to him: 'Seek war booty from sources other than your brother's property.' Regarding a horse, the Muslim are one hand, supporting each other. Regarding the verse 'The adulterer shall not marry except an adulteress or a polytheist...' (Surah An-Nur 24:3), Aflah narrated from the Prophet ﷺ: 'The adulterer who has been whipped does not marry except an adulteress who has been whipped, and the adulteress who has been whipped is not married except to an adulterer who has been whipped, and this is forbidden to the believers.' The Imam narrated regarding the Prophet's ﷺ method that he did not perform qunut at all during his prayer, nor did the two caliphs after him.

potential_issues.impact: The chain starts with Aflah ibn Abd al-Wahhab and Abu Ghanim al-Khorasani, both of whom are classified as Majhul (unknown). This creates a significant reliability problem at the outset of the chain, making the entire hadith questionable regardless of the reliability of subsequent narrators.

Qatadah ibn Di'amah is classified as a Mudallis (specifically Category 3 - one who practices tadlis). He uses the indirect transmission term 'an (عَنْ) with Anas ibn Malik. According to hadith methodology, direct hearing (sami'tu or haddathana) would be required to validate his report from Anas. However, given that Anas lived until 93 AH and Qatadah until 118 AH, they were contemporaries and Qatadah likely did hear from Anas. Nevertheless, the use of 'an rather than a direct transmission term is a methodological concern.

english_translation: Narrated by al-Imam (Aflah ibn Abd al-Wahhab): From Abu Ghanim al-Khorasani, from Hatim ibn Mansur. Hatim reported: 'I narrated from someone whose statement I do not suspect from among our companions, while I was in Egypt or on the way to Egypt, from Abu Ahhayf al-Hadhrami, the jurist of the people of Egypt, from Ibn Imranah. He mentioned that Qunut in Fajr prayer - after I asked him whether the Messenger ﷺ performed Qunut. He said to me: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ did not do it. When I asked how he performed it according to what reached him, he said: It reached me that when he finished the last recitation, he recited Surah al-Ikhlas and did not perform Qunut. The Imam said: We had not seen this matter in the books of our companions nor heard it from them until Abu Ghanim brought it to us, so we narrated it from him.'

chainIssues: Entire chain consists of unknown narrators (Majhul)

potential_issues.impact: Every single narrator in this chain is classified as Majhul (unknown). The original identity of most narrators cannot be established with certainty. This is a fundamental breach of hadith authenticity standards.

Hatim ibn Mansur explicitly states he narrated from 'someone whose statement I do not suspect' without naming this person. An unnamed narrator (عمّن لا أتهم) creates a discontinuity in the chain (انقطاع) that breaks the requirements for a valid isnad. This narrator is described only by a vague descriptor rather than an actual name.

The chain originates from Egypt through Abu Ahhayf and Ibn Imranah, neither of whom appear in standard hadith sources or collector works. This geographic isolation and lack of corroboration in established collections raises serious authenticity concerns.

Aflah's statement that this material was not found in established sources until brought by Abu Ghanim indicates the narrators themselves were aware this was unusual transmission. This acknowledgment further weakens the chain's reliability.

english_translation: Narrated by al-Imam (Aflah ibn Abd al-Wahhab): It reached me from the Messenger of Allah ﷺ that he sent a military expedition and appointed a leader over them. This leader would perform prayer with his companions with only the Opening Chapter (Surah al-Fatihah) and Surah al-Ikhlas throughout all his prayers - the morning prayer and others - in everything he made them hear regarding loud recitation. When they came to the Prophet ﷺ, they informed him that their leader only prayed with them using al-Fatihah and Surah al-Ikhlas and did not recite anything else in all his prayers. The Prophet ﷺ asked him: 'Do you have something from the Quran?' He replied: 'Yes.' He said: 'What prevented you from reciting it in your prayer?' He said: 'O Messenger of Allah ﷺ, I love Surah al-Ikhlas with a strong love.' The Prophet ﷺ remained silent, then turned to the man and said: 'Indeed, Allah loves you for your love of Surah al-Ikhlas.' The Imam also reported from the scholars among us: The Prophet ﷺ entered the mosque and saw people raising their hands in prayer like the tails of wild horses, so he said: 'What is with these people raising their hands in prayer like the tails of wild horses? Be still during your prayer and know that Allah is closer to you than the jugular vein.'

chainIssues: Mursal transmission (balaghani) - the hadith does not establish a complete chain to the Prophet ﷺ

potential_issues.impact: The hadith is explicitly transmitted using 'balaghani' (بَلَغَنِي - 'it reached me'), which is a form of mursal transmission. This means the chain is not completely connected from the narrator to the Prophet ﷺ. In classical hadith methodology, mursal hadiths are generally considered weak unless corroborated by other chains.

Aflah ibn Abd al-Wahhab is classified as Majhul. When a Majhul narrator transmits via mursal, the reliability becomes even more questionable because there is no documentation of which intermediate sources brought this information to him.

The use of 'balaghani' without any specification of how or through whom this information reached the narrator creates ambiguity about the authenticity of the report. Multiple scenarios could explain how the information reached him.

english_translation: Narrated by Jabir ibn Zayd that a man came to the Messenger of Allah ﷺ who was from his maternal uncles, and his name was Dimam ibn Tha'labah. He said to him: 'O Messenger of Allah, I am from your maternal uncles, from Banu Jushaym.' The Prophet ﷺ had been nursed among them. He said: 'I will question you and be strict in my questioning, so do not take offense.' The Prophet ﷺ said to him: 'Ask about your need.' He said: 'Who created you and created those before you and will create those after you?' He said: 'Allah.' He said: 'I adjure you by Him, did He send you?' The Prophet of Allah said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Who created the seven heavens and seven earths, and who provides sustenance between them?' He said: 'Allah.' He said: 'I adjure you by Him, did He send you?' He said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Your messengers informed us and we found in your books that we should pray five prayers each day and night. I adjure you by Him, did He command you with this?' The Prophet ﷺ said: 'Yes.' He said: 'Your messengers informed us and we found in your books that you should take Zakat from our wealthy and place it among our poor. I adjure you by Him, did He command you?' The Prophet ﷺ said: 'O Allah, yes.' He said: 'Your messengers informed us and we found in your books that we should fast the month of Ramadan each year. I adjure you by Him, did He command you with this?' He said ﷺ: 'O Allah, yes.' He said: 'Your messengers informed us and we found in your books that we should perform Hajj to the House of Allah if we find provision and transportation. I adjure you by Allah, did He command you with this?' He said: 'O Allah, yes.' The man said: 'And the fifth, I have no desire to ask you about it,' meaning the prohibited things. He said: 'If you had permitted them, the world would not survive by them, and if you had not forbidden them, the religion would not stand by them.' Then he said: 'I am returning to my people and will act according to them, and whoever follows me from my people.' The Prophet ﷺ said when he departed: 'If the man is truthful, he will enter Paradise.'
